Welcome to HomeGroup

Your complete Home Group management portal for meeting schedules, member tracking, Group Conscience decisions, and fellowship activities. All data is stored securely in your browser for privacy and anonymity.

        User Guide & Instructions

        Complete guide to using the HomeGroup Management Portal for daily operations and Group Conscience meetings.

        Application Overview

        This is a comprehensive Home Group Management System designed specifically for AA groups. All data is stored locally in your browser using localStorage, ensuring privacy and anonymity. The application works offline after the initial load and requires no server or external database.

        Complete Feature Set (100+ Features)

        Meeting Management (13)

        Schedule & calendar, format rotation, commitment board, secretary functions, meeting companion, attendance analytics, role rotation, virtual meeting integration, QR check-in, feedback surveys, speaker booking, chip ceremonies

        Fellowship & Engagement (19)

        Birthdays & anniversaries, attendance streaks, wellness checks, newcomer tracking, sponsors, temp sponsor matching, emergency contacts, topic suggestions, 12-step calls, problem box, announcements, messaging, photo gallery, temperature check, satisfaction survey, communications lists, reminders, action items, welcome packets

        Group Conscience (16)

        Live GC sessions, emergency GC, decision history, motion templates, parliamentary procedure, tradition checker, tradition moments, spiritual principles, unity checker, inventory, inventory questions, tradition study, concept study, conflict resolution, by-laws repository, voting settings

        Financial Management (12)

        Financial reports, budget approval, contribution comparison, expense approval workflow, bill reminders, contribution calculator, financial goals tracker, receipt upload, quarterly reports, 7th tradition analysis, prudent reserve, chip inventory

        Group Service (8)

        Service positions, elections, opportunities board, sponsorship tracking, sponsorship tree visualization, H&I meeting commitments, service hours tracking, group special events

        District & Area Service (11)

        District/Area committee, District motions, Service structure, Area Assembly integration, Intergroup representative, H&I panel management, CPC, PI, treatment facilities, corrections, language accessibility

        Home Group Specific (6)

        Inter-group connections, home group transfers, benefits tracking, commitment levels, group census, growth metrics

        Literature & Resources (11)

        Daily reflections, step tracker, Big Book study tracker, literature inventory, literature loans, newcomer packs, literature sales, digital library, study guide generator, document templates, group history

        Reports & Analytics (6)

        Chairperson reports, meeting minutes, group analytics, participation analytics, financial health, decision impact tracking

        Integration & Mobile (10)

        Google Calendar export, SMS integration, email automation, cloud backup, multi-group support, AA meeting finder, offline mode, mobile features, touch gestures, PWA app install

        Accessibility (6)

        Accessibility settings, multi-language support, large print mode, screen reader optimization, closed captioning, accessibility committee

        Archival & History (5)

        Digital archive, oral history collection, group milestones, member legacy tributes, historical minutes search

        Area & District Service (10)

        Area Assembly integration, Intergroup representative, H&I panel management, CPC professional community, PI public information, treatment facilities liaison, corrections committee, special events management, archives management, language accessibility

        Data Privacy & Security

        Your data never leaves your device. All information is stored in your browser's localStorage. Make regular backups using the Backup & Restore feature in Settings.

        Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

        Quick answers to the most common questions!

        Data & Privacy

        Q: Is my data secure? Does it go to a server?

        A: Your data NEVER leaves your device. Everything is stored in your browser's localStorage, not on any server. This maintains complete anonymity and privacy.

        Q: What happens if I clear my browser data?

        A: You'll lose all data permanently unless you have a backup. Always export backups weekly via Settings Backup & Restore.

        Q: Can I access this on multiple devices?

        A: Yes! Export backup from device #1, then import on device #2. Data doesn't auto-sync, so manually transfer when needed.

        Q: How do I share data with other service positions?

        A: Export backup JSON file, share via USB/email/cloud storage, then each person imports it. Multiple people can edit simultaneously if you coordinate who saves when.

        Getting Started

        Q: Where do I start? The system looks overwhelming!

        A: Start simple: (1) Add 5-10 members in Fellowship Birthdays & Anniversaries, (2) Add your meeting schedule, (3) Add current service positions. That's enough to begin! Explore other features gradually.

        Q: Do I need to fill out everything?

        A: No! Use only what your group needs. Many groups use just 10-15 features regularly. The system is comprehensive but flexible - ignore features you don't need.

        Q: Why are all the dropdowns empty?

        A: Add members first! Most dropdowns populate from your member list. Go to Fellowship Birthdays & Anniversaries and add members.

        Backup & Recovery

        Q: How often should I backup?

        A: Weekly minimum, after every GC meeting recommended. Set a phone reminder every Sunday night!

        Q: Where should I save backups?

        A: Multiple locations: (1) USB drive, (2) Cloud storage (Google Drive/Dropbox), (3) Email to group secretary. Never rely on one location!

        Q: Can I restore an old backup without losing current data?

        A: Export current data first as backup, THEN import old backup. Importing overwrites everything. Always export before importing!

        Group Conscience

        Q: Do we really need to use the Live GC Session feature?

        A: No, but it makes GC meetings smoother! You can record decisions manually in Decision History. Live GC Session helps during the meeting with real-time voting and tracking.

        Q: What if we don't have substantial unanimity (2/3 vote)?

        A: Options: (1) Activate research period for more info, (2) Table motion for next meeting, (3) Motion fails. The system tracks this automatically.

        Q: Can we change our voting method (substantial unanimity vs majority)?

        A: Yes! Go to Group Conscience Voting Settings. This should be a group conscience decision. AA recommends substantial unanimity (2/3).

        Service Positions

        Q: System says service position expires soon - what do I do?

        A: 30 days before expiration: (1) Announce at meeting, (2) Add election to next GC agenda, (3) Conduct election, (4) Update position holder in system.

        Q: What if no one wants to serve in a position?

        A: Options: (1) Combine with another position temporarily, (2) Reduce term length (6 months instead of 12), (3) Request help from District, (4) Group operates with vacant position temporarily.

        Technical Issues

        Q: System is running slow / charts won't load.

        A: (1) Check storage usage in Settings, (2) Archive old data (export first!), (3) Clear old photos from gallery, (4) Try different browser (Chrome/Edge/Firefox recommended).

        Q: I accidentally deleted important data. Can I get it back?

        A: Only if you have a backup. There's no "undo" function. Import your most recent backup via Settings Backup & Restore. THIS IS WHY WEEKLY BACKUPS ARE CRITICAL!

        Q: Can I print reports for members without computers?

        A: Yes! Most reports have "Export to PDF" buttons. Print treasurer report, GC minutes, meeting schedules, etc. Use browser print function (Ctrl+P) for any page.

        Common Crisis Scenarios & Solutions

        Real-world problems require real-world solutions! These scenarios will happen - here's how to handle them using this system.

        CRISIS 1: Treasurer Resigns Unexpectedly Mid-Term

        Situation:

        Your treasurer quit without notice. No handoff, incomplete records, unclear bank access.

        Immediate Actions (Within 24 Hours):

        1. Emergency GC Meeting: Navigate to Home Click "Emergency GC Protocol" button in Quick Actions panel. Document the situation.
        2. Appoint Interim Treasurer: Vote for temporary treasurer until proper election. Record in Emergency GC session.
        3. Secure Bank Access: If former treasurer was only signer, contact bank immediately with group EIN. May need group chair/secretary to co-sign.
        4. Export Last Backup: Settings (gear icon) Backup & Restore Find most recent backup. This has financial history.

        Within 1 Week:

        1. Reconstruct Finances: Treasury Financial Reports Enter all transactions from bank statements
        2. Verify Prudent Reserve: Treasury Prudent Reserve Recalculate and update
        3. Schedule Proper Election: Add to next GC agenda for permanent treasurer
        4. Update Service Position: Service Service Positions Update treasurer record with interim person

        Prevention for Future:

        • Require TWO signers on bank account (treasurer + one other)
        • Weekly backups stored in multiple locations
        • Monthly reconciliation reports to group
        • Shadow treasurer system (assistant learns the role)

        CRISIS 2: Group Split / Fracture

        Situation:

        Significant portion of group (30-40%) wants to leave and form new meeting due to disagreements.

        Immediate Actions:

        1. Emergency Group Conscience: Home Emergency GC Protocol Hold emergency GC to discuss. Document all perspectives with minority opinions.
        2. Facilitate Compassionate Dialogue: Group Conscience Unity Checker Use to identify divisive issues. Focus on principles, not personalities.
        3. If Split Is Inevitable: Accept with grace. Better two healthy groups than one divided group.

        Asset Division (If Split Happens):

        1. Financial Split: Treasury Financial Reports Export current balance Agree on division (often proportional to members, or 50/50)
        2. Literature Inventory: Resources Literature Inventory Export list Divide pamphlets, books, chips fairly
        3. Data Export for New Group: Settings Backup & Restore Export full backup New group imports and modifies
        4. Member Records: Members choose which group to join. Export member list, each group keeps only their members. Delete others for privacy.

        After Split:

        • Update Service Structure: Both groups register separately with District/Area/Intergroup
        • Document History: Resources Group History Record the split compassionately ("Group divided into [Group A] and [Group B] on [date] to better serve members")
        • Maintain Unity: Both groups are still AA. Encourage members to attend both if helpful.
        • New Group Setup: New group follows First-Time Setup guide in this help section

        CRISIS 3: Active Member Death

        Situation:

        Long-time or active member passes away. Group needs to respond compassionately while respecting anonymity.

        Immediate Actions (Day 1-3):

        1. Verify Information: Confirm death through reliable source (family, close friends). Never assume.
        2. Announce at Meeting: Chairperson makes brief announcement. Offer moment of silence. Keep it simple and dignified.
        3. Check Service Commitments: Service Service Positions If deceased held position, schedule emergency election
        4. Fellowship Announcements: Post group announcement about member's passing (first name only for anonymity)

        Memorial Considerations:

        1. Family Wishes: Contact family if possible. Do they want AA presence at funeral? Many families appreciate AA attendance.
        2. AA Memorial Service? Hold group conscience vote: Group Conscience Live GC Session "Hold memorial speaker meeting in honor of [First Name]"
        3. If Yes to Memorial: Service Group Special Events Create memorial event Book speakers who knew the person

        System Updates:

        1. Create Legacy Tribute: Resources Member Legacy Add tribute page with:
          • First name only
          • Sobriety date and length
          • Service positions held
          • Impact on group (brief)
          • Date of passing
          • NO LAST NAME (anonymity even in death)
        2. Update Member Status: Fellowship Birthdays & Anniversaries Mark member as "Deceased" (don't delete - preserves history)
        3. Archive Photos: If in photo gallery, move to historical section with respectful caption

        Anonymity Reminders:

        • Newspaper obituaries: Family decides, not group. If mentioned, use "was active in AA" not "was an alcoholic"
        • Social media: NEVER post member's full name + AA affiliation
        • Group photos: If deceased in group photos, no need to remove - part of history

        CRISIS 4: Financial Emergency - Can't Pay Rent

        Situation:

        Treasury is depleted, rent due in 7 days, insufficient 7th tradition contributions.

        Immediate Actions (Day 1):

        1. Verify Numbers: Treasury Financial Reports Check actual balance. Confirm rent amount and due date.
        2. Calculate Gap: Treasury Prudent Reserve How much short? Be specific: "We need $437 by Friday"
        3. Emergency GC: Home Emergency GC Protocol Present financial facts clearly

        Within 3 Days:

        1. Announce at ALL Meetings: Fellowship Announcements Post clear, factual announcement: "Group treasury is $XXX short for rent due on [date]. Please consider extra 7th tradition contribution if able. This is our home and we need your support."
        2. Contact District/Area: District & Area District Committee Request emergency assistance. Most Districts have contingency funds for group emergencies.
        3. Cut Non-Essential Expenses: Treasury Budget Approval Temporarily suspend literature orders, special projects

        Solutions (Choose based on Group Conscience):

        • One-Time Appeal: Members who can contribute extra this month (not required, strictly voluntary)
        • District Loan: Short-term loan from District (must be repaid, track in Treasury Financial Reports)
        • Temporary Meeting Move: Find free location temporarily (church, community center, member's home) until treasury rebuilds
        • Literature Sale: Sell excess literature inventory back to Intergroup for cash
        • Fundraising Event: AA-appropriate (speaker meeting, workshop) with suggested donations

        Long-Term Prevention:

        1. Monthly Education: Treasury 7th Tradition Analysis Share contribution trends at business meeting. Educate on group self-support.
        2. Prudent Reserve Goal: Treasury Prudent Reserve Set 3-month reserve. Work toward this goal monthly.
        3. Contribution Calculator: Treasury Group Contribution Calculator Show members suggested per-person contribution: "[Rent + Expenses] [Average Attendance] = $X per person"
        4. Transparency: Post monthly financial report on wall. Members support what they understand.

        CRISIS 5: Newcomer in Immediate Crisis

        Situation:

        Member/newcomer calls at 2am actively drinking, suicidal, or in danger. How to respond?

        Immediate Response (SAFETY FIRST):

        1. Assess Immediate Danger:
          • If suicidal/medical emergency: CALL 911 FIRST. Stay on phone until help arrives. AA is not a replacement for professional help.
          • If actively drinking but safe: Activate 12-step call list
          • If just needs to talk: Talk with them, offer to meet for coffee tomorrow
        2. Access 12-Step Call Roster: Fellowship 12-Step Call Roster Call members on list in order until someone answers
        3. Two-Person Response: NEVER go alone to stranger's house at night. Always send 2 members for safety.

        During 12-Step Call:

        • Meet in public place if possible (24-hour diner, etc.)
        • Share your story, let them talk
        • Offer meeting schedule, phone numbers
        • Do NOT: Drive them around, give money, take them home, become their therapist
        • Safety first - if situation feels unsafe, leave and call authorities

        Follow-Up (Next Day):

        1. Document (Minimal): Fellowship 12-Step Call Roster Log call date and outcome only. NO details (privacy!).
        2. Assign Temporary Sponsor: Fellowship Temporary Sponsor Matching Connect person with temp sponsor ASAP
        3. Wellness Check: Fellowship Member Wellness Check Schedule follow-up calls at 1 week, 2 weeks, 30 days
        4. Connect to Services: If needed, provide contact info for treatment centers (Treatment Facilities list), detox, counseling

        What NOT to Document:

        • Details of what they said (suicidal thoughts, trauma, etc.)
        • Medical information
        • Legal issues mentioned
        • Family problems discussed
        • ONLY: Date of call, who responded, outcome (came to meeting / referred to treatment / declined help)

        CRISIS 6: Sudden Loss of Meeting Location

        Situation:

        Church/facility gives 30-day notice that group must move. Or worse - effective immediately.

        Immediate Actions (Day 1):

        1. Emergency GC: Home Emergency GC Protocol Discuss situation and form search committee
        2. Activate Phone Tree: Fellowship Messages Send emergency notification to all members with contact info
        3. Update Meeting Directories ASAP: District & Area Intergroup Representative Contact IR immediately to update meeting finder, AA.org, local directory

        Finding New Location (Week 1):

        1. Search Committee: Assign 2-3 members. Track prospects in system:
          • Fellowship Action Items Create action item "Find new meeting location" with deadline
          • Track potential locations in notes
        2. Location Options:
          • Other churches (most welcoming)
          • Community centers
          • Libraries (daytime meetings)
          • Hospital conference rooms
          • Member's home (temporary emergency option)
          • Outdoor pavilion (weather-dependent)
        3. Contact District for Help: District & Area District Committee District has list of AA-friendly facilities

        Transition (Weeks 2-4):

        1. Vote on New Location: Present options at GC, vote using substantial unanimity
        2. Update System: Meetings Schedule & Calendar Edit meeting Update location address
        3. Update ALL Directories: AA.org, Intergroup website, Google Maps, local directories, fliers
        4. Post Signs at Old Location: "Meeting has moved to [new address]. See you there!"
        5. Announce for 4 Weeks: At EVERY meeting, announce new location. Visitors may not know.

        Document in System:

        • Resources Group History Add milestone: "Group relocated from [old address] to [new address] on [date]"
        • Group Conscience Decision History Record decision to move and vote tally

        Additional Crisis Resources

        Remember: You don't have to handle crises alone!

        • District Support: Your DCM can provide guidance and resources
        • Area Helpline: Most areas have experienced members available for consultation
        • GSO Resources: AA.org has pamphlets on group problems
        • Experienced Groups: Call GSR from long-established group for advice
        • Old-Timers: Members with 20+ years often have seen it all - ask for wisdom

        Color Schema Guide

        The application uses a consistent color-coding system to help you navigate quickly:

        Blue (#3498db)

        General features, meetings, schedules, information sections

        Purple (#9b59b6)

        Group Conscience features, voting, decisions, parliamentary procedure

        Green (#2ecc71)

        Service positions, positive outcomes, consent agenda, approved items

        Gold (#f1c40f)

        Treasury, financial reports, budget, 7th tradition, prudent reserve

        Orange (#f39c12)

        Announcements, birthdays, warnings, amendments, ROI calculations

        Red (#e74c3c)

        Emergency GC, critical actions, tabled motions, decision reversals

        Teal (#1abc9c)

        Reports, analytics, chairperson functions, implementation tracking

        Gray (#95a5a6)

        Templates, resources, history, archived items, neutral information

        Day-to-Day Operations Guide

        Daily Tasks

        1. Check Dashboard (Home Section)

        • Review upcoming events and birthdays
        • Check active announcements
        • Monitor service position status
        • Review pending GC action items

        2. Before Each Meeting (Schedule Section)

        • Navigate to Meetings Schedule & Calendar
        • Verify meeting time and location
        • Check format rotation (Meetings Format Rotation)
        • Review commitment board (Meetings Commitment Board)
        • Prepare secretary notes if needed

        3. During Meetings (Secretary Functions)

        • Go to Meetings Secretary Functions
        • Record attendance using the attendance tracker
        • Take meeting minutes in real-time
        • Log 7th tradition contributions
        • Track who shares (if applicable)

        4. Weekly Treasurer Tasks (Treasury Sections)

        • Finance Financial Reports: Update income/expenses
        • Finance 7th Tradition Analysis: Review contribution trends
        • Finance Prudent Reserve: Monitor reserve target
        • Generate monthly financial reports when needed

        5. Service Position Management (Service Section)

        • Service Service Positions: Track current positions
        • Monitor term expiration dates
        • Prepare for elections 30 days before term ends
        • Update position holders after elections

        Group Conscience Meeting Workflow

        Group Conscience meetings are the spiritual authority of the group. This application helps facilitate informed, organized, and spiritually principled decision-making.

        BEFORE the GC Meeting (1-2 Weeks Prior)

        Step 1: Collect Agenda Items

        1. Navigate to Group Conscience Decision History
        2. Scroll to "Proposed Agenda Items" section
        3. Members submit items they want to discuss
        4. Include: Title, Description, Category, Financial Impact
        5. Mark items for consent agenda if they're routine

        Step 2: Review Standing/Recurring Items

        1. Scroll to "Standing/Recurring Agenda Items"
        2. Review items that appear regularly (monthly, quarterly, etc.)
        3. These automatically populate based on their frequency

        Step 3: Generate & Send Agenda

        1. Scroll to "Email Integration" section
        2. Set meeting date and recipient list
        3. Click "Generate & Email Agenda"
        4. Review items via your email client

        Step 4: Research Period (Optional but Recommended)

        1. For major decisions, set a research period
        2. Members can ask questions and gather information
        3. Use the Discussion Thread feature for each item

        DURING the GC Meeting

        Step 1: Start Live GC Session

        1. Navigate to Group Conscience Live GC Session
        2. Click "Start Group Conscience Meeting"
        3. This activates the live session interface

        Step 2: Handle Consent Agenda (Optional)

        1. Scroll to "Consent Agenda"
        2. Items marked for consent are listed here
        3. These can be approved in bulk without discussion
        4. Any member can "pull" an item for full discussion
        5. Click "Approve Consent Agenda" for remaining items

        Step 3: Process Regular Agenda Items

        1. Add each item to the live GC queue
        2. For each motion:
          • Motion made: Record who made it
          • Second required: Click "Call for Second"
          • Discussion: Add discussion comments
          • Amendments: Use amendment feature if motion is modified
          • Vote: Record votes (For/Against/Abstain)

        Step 4: Parliamentary Procedures

        Use Group Conscience Parliamentary Procedure for:

        • Point of Order: Challenge procedural violations
        • Point of Information: Ask clarifying questions
        • Point of Privilege: Address immediate needs
        • Table Motion: Postpone discussion (requires date)
        • Call the Question: End discussion and vote
        • Minority Opinion: Record dissenting views

        Step 5: Check Traditions & Concepts

        1. Go to Group Conscience Tradition & Concept Checker
        2. Before voting, verify decision aligns with AA principles
        3. System highlights potential conflicts

        Step 6: Record Final Decision

        1. After voting, decision is saved to Decision History
        2. Record any action items created
        3. Assign responsible parties and deadlines

        AFTER the GC Meeting

        Step 1: Generate Minutes

        1. Go to "Email Integration" section
        2. Click "Generate & Email Minutes"
        3. Minutes include all decisions, votes, and action items

        Step 2: Track Implementation

        1. Scroll to "Decision Implementation Tracking"
        2. Select the decision to track
        3. Update progress regularly (0-100%)
        4. Mark milestones achieved
        5. Change status as needed (Planned/In Progress/Completed/Blocked)

        Step 3: Monitor Action Items

        1. Check Home dashboard for pending action items
        2. System sends reminders as deadlines approach
        3. Update progress and mark complete when done

        Step 4: Member Voting History

        1. Go to "Member Voting History"
        2. Track participation rates
        3. Identify patterns in voting
        4. Useful for understanding group consciousness

        Special GC Features

        Motion Reconsideration

        To reconsider a past decision:

        1. Select the original decision from dropdown
        2. Provide detailed justification with new information
        3. Set research period if needed
        4. Submit for group review
        5. Note: Reconsideration should be rare and only with substantial new information

        Proxy Voting

        Check your group guidelines first! Not all groups allow proxy voting.

        1. Designate someone to vote on your behalf
        2. Choose General (vote as they see fit) or Directed (specific instructions)
        3. Valid only for the specified meeting date
        4. Can be revoked anytime before the meeting

        Emergency Group Conscience

        For urgent matters requiring immediate attention:

        1. Go to Home dashboard
        2. Click "Emergency GC Protocol" button in Quick Actions panel
        3. Document the emergency situation
        4. Notify members immediately
        5. Follow expedited decision process

        Decision ROI Calculator

        For financial decisions, calculate impact before voting:

        1. Enter initial cost and ongoing costs
        2. Input expected revenue impact or expense savings
        3. Set timeframe (months)
        4. Review net impact and payback period
        5. System provides recommendation (positive/neutral/negative)

        Decision Reversal Tracking

        Learn from past changes to avoid future issues:

        1. Record when a decision is reversed
        2. Document why it was reversed
        3. Note lessons learned
        4. Track patterns in reversal reasons
        5. Use insights to improve future decisions

        Keyboard Shortcuts

        Alt + H
        Go to Home
        Alt + G
        Go to Live GC
        Alt + S
        Go to Settings
        Alt + B
        Create Backup

        Troubleshooting & Tips

        Data Backup (CRITICAL)

        IMPORTANT: Your data is stored locally in your browser. If you clear browser data or switch devices, you'll lose everything unless you have a backup!
        • Go to Settings (gear icon) Backup & Restore
        • Click "Export Full Backup" weekly
        • Save the JSON file to a safe location
        • Test your backup by importing it on another device

        Browser Compatibility

        • Works best in Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari
        • Requires JavaScript enabled
        • Works offline after initial load
        • Mobile-friendly responsive design

        Common Issues

        Dropdowns are empty

        • Add members first in Fellowship Birthdays & Anniversaries
        • Dropdowns auto-populate from member list

        Charts not displaying

        • Ensure you have data entered for that feature
        • Charts require Chart.js library (loaded automatically online)

        Lost data after clearing browser

        • Restore from your backup JSON file
        • Go to Settings Backup & Restore Import

        Slow performance

        • Check storage usage in Settings
        • Consider archiving old data
        • Export and clean up old photos

        AA Principles Integration

        This application is designed to support the 12 Traditions and 12 Concepts for World Service:

        How This App Supports the Traditions

        • Tradition 1 (Unity): Unity Checker helps identify divisive issues
        • Tradition 2 (Group Conscience): Comprehensive GC tools ensure informed decisions
        • Tradition 4 (Autonomy): Fully customizable to your group's needs
        • Tradition 5 (Primary Purpose): Keeps focus on recovery through organized service
        • Tradition 7 (Self-Supporting): 7th Tradition tracking and analysis
        • Tradition 8 (Non-Professional): Tracks volunteer service, not employment
        • Tradition 9 (Minimal Organization): Streamlined, non-bureaucratic structure
        • Tradition 12 (Anonymity): All data stays on your device, no servers

        12 Concepts Integration

        • Concept I (Final Responsibility): Group Conscience is the ultimate authority
        • Concept II (Delegated Authority): Service position tracking with clear roles
        • Concept III (Right of Decision): Trusted servants make decisions within scope
        • Concept IV (Participation): Member voting history promotes engagement
        • Concept V (Right of Appeal/Petition): Reconsideration workflow built-in
        • Concept XII (Warranty of Conference): Tradition checker ensures adherence

        Area & District Service Features - Detailed Usage Guide

        Comprehensive Service Work Tools These 10 features support your group's service structure work at the district, area, and local level.

        Area Assembly Integration

        Purpose: Track Area Assembly activities, motions, and your GSR's voting instructions from the group.

        How to Use:

        • Assembly Motions: Add motions that will be discussed at Area Assembly. Record title, description, financial impact, and your group's position.
        • GSR Voting Instructions: Before each assembly, your group can provide specific voting instructions to the GSR on important motions.
        • Assembly Reports: After each assembly, your GSR can log a detailed report including attendance, key decisions, and committee updates.
        • Standing Committees: Track which standing committees (PI, CPC, Treatment, etc.) your members serve on and their contact information.

        Typical Workflow: Before assembly Group discusses upcoming motions Record group conscience position GSR attends assembly GSR logs report after assembly

        Intergroup Representative Functions

        Purpose: Manage Intergroup Representative (IR) duties including meetings, hotline, and special events.

        How to Use:

        • Intergroup Notes: Log notes from monthly Intergroup meetings including date, key topics, decisions, and action items for your group.
        • Hotline Scheduling: Coordinate AA hotline coverage by assigning volunteers to specific days/time slots. Track contact info and shift preferences.
        • Special Events: Document Intergroup special events (conferences, workshops, speaker meetings) with dates, locations, and your group's participation.
        • Group Liaison Activities: Track your group's relationship with Intergroup, financial contributions, and any group concerns to bring to Intergroup.

        Typical Workflow: IR attends monthly Intergroup Logs meeting notes Coordinates hotline volunteers Reports back to home group Tracks special events

        H&I Panel Management

        Purpose: Comprehensive management of Hospitals & Institutions panel commitments and volunteers.

        How to Use:

        • H&I Facilities: Add facilities your panel serves (hospitals, detox centers, rehabs). Include facility name, type, contact person, address, and meeting schedule.
        • Panel Schedules: Create recurring panel commitments by selecting facility, lead member, backup, and meeting time. Track how many times each panel has met.
        • Orientations: Log when members complete H&I orientation training. Required before members can participate in panels.
        • Certifications: Track special certifications needed for certain facilities (background checks, facility-specific training, COVID vaccinations, etc.).

        Typical Workflow: New facility added Schedule recurring panels Members complete orientation Assign to panels Track certifications Monitor panel attendance

        CPC (Cooperation with Professional Community)

        Purpose: Build relationships with professionals who encounter alcoholics (doctors, counselors, clergy, lawyers, employers).

        How to Use:

        • Professional Contacts: Maintain database of professional contacts including name, profession, organization, contact info, and last contact date.
        • Presentations: Schedule and track presentations to professional groups. Log presentation date, audience, location, attendees, and follow-up notes.
        • BTG Referrals: Bridge-the-Gap program connects newcomers from treatment with AA members. Track referrals, assign volunteers, and monitor follow-up contacts.
        • Literature Distribution: Track literature distributed to professionals (pamphlets like "AA for the Health Professional", "If You Are A Professional").

        Typical Workflow: Build professional relationships Schedule presentations Distribute literature Manage BTG referrals Follow up with both professionals and newcomers

        PI (Public Information)

        Purpose: Inform the general public about AA through media contacts, press releases, and community outreach.

        How to Use:

        • Media Contacts: Maintain list of media contacts (reporters, editors, producers). Include outlet, contact info, beat/specialty, and relationship notes.
        • Press Releases: Draft and track press releases for AA Awareness Month, National Recovery Month, or correcting misinformation. Save drafts and track which outlets received them.
        • Outreach Events: Log community outreach activities (health fairs, resource expos, school presentations). Track what materials were distributed and estimated reach.
        • Outreach Log: Detailed log of all PI activities including date, type, volunteers involved, materials used, and outcomes/follow-up needed.

        Typical Workflow: Build media relationships Draft press releases when needed Attend community events Track all outreach Report to group and area

        Treatment Facilities Liaison

        Purpose: Coordinate with treatment centers to bring meetings to residents and support them as they transition out.

        How to Use:

        • Treatment Facilities: Add treatment centers your group serves. Include facility name, type (inpatient/outpatient), address, contact person, and meeting schedule.
        • Bridging Commitments: Schedule volunteers to meet with residents before discharge and help them connect with local AA. Track volunteer, facility, date, and how many residents met.
        • Follow-Up Tracking: After discharge, track follow-up contacts with former residents. Did they attend meetings? Do they need temporary sponsor? Record outcomes.
        • Literature for Facilities: Track what literature you provide to treatment centers and when it needs replenishing.

        Typical Workflow: Establish facility relationship Schedule meetings at facility Coordinate bridging volunteers Meet residents before discharge Follow up after discharge Track outcomes

        Corrections Committee

        Purpose: Bring AA message to incarcerated individuals and support their reentry into the community.

        How to Use:

        • Correctional Facilities: Add facilities your committee serves (jails, prisons). Include facility name, security level, address, contact, and meeting schedule.
        • Facility Clearances: Track which members have clearance to enter facilities. Record member, facility, clearance date, expiration, and badge number. Most facilities require background checks.
        • Pre-Release Contact Program: Connect inmates nearing release with outside AA members. Match inmate with contact person, record anticipated release date, and track actual release and follow-up.
        • Correspondence Log: Some inmates can't attend meetings but want correspondence. Track pen-pal matches between inmates and outside members, ensuring anonymity is maintained.

        Typical Workflow: Members obtain clearances Schedule facility meetings Connect pre-release inmates with outside contacts Maintain correspondence program Support reentry

        Special Events Management

        Purpose: Plan and execute group special events like speaker meetings, anniversary celebrations, workshops, and conferences.

        How to Use:

        • Event Management: Create events with title, type, date, location, expected attendance, and coordinator. Track event status (Planning/Confirmed/Completed/Cancelled).
        • Speaker Booking: Track speakers for the event including name, topic, contact info, speaking fee (if any), and confirmation status. Schedule multiple speakers for larger events.
        • Volunteer Coordination: Sign up volunteers for different roles (setup, registration, refreshments, cleanup, greeter, etc.). Assign each volunteer to specific tasks.
        • Budget Tracking: Enter expected costs (venue, food, literature, speaker travel) and actual expenses. Track budget vs actual spending with variance reporting.
        • Ticket Sales: If charging admission, track ticket price, quantity sold, and revenue. Monitor ticket sales progress and revenue vs expenses.

        Typical Workflow: Plan event Book speakers Recruit volunteers Set budget Sell tickets Execute event Track actual costs Report to group

        Archives Management

        Purpose: Preserve your group's history through document archiving and oral histories from long-time members.

        How to Use:

        • Digital Archives: Index historical documents by title, date, category (meeting minutes, financial records, correspondence, photos, event materials). Add descriptions and search by decade or category.
        • Old-Timer Interviews: Record oral history interviews with long-time members. Document interviewee name, clean date, years in group, interviewer, interview date, and key stories/highlights.
        • Search & Filter: Use category and decade filters to quickly find specific types of historical documents. Search archives by title or description.
        • Historical Timeline: Build a timeline of significant group events, founding date, major decisions, facility moves, and member milestones.

        Typical Workflow: Collect historical documents Index and categorize Interview old-timers Record stories Build searchable archive Share history with group

        Language Accessibility

        Purpose: Make AA accessible to non-English speakers through translation, interpretation, and multilingual materials.

        How to Use:

        • Translator Registry: Maintain list of bilingual members who can translate materials. Record member, languages they speak, fluency level (conversational/professional), and availability.
        • Translated Materials: Track what AA literature and materials have been translated. Document material title, source language, target language, translator, completion date, and where copies are stored.
        • Interpreter Scheduling: Schedule interpreters for specific meetings or events. Assign interpreter, date/time, meeting type, language pair, and special notes (technical topics, etc.).
        • Closed Captioning: For virtual meetings, coordinate closed captioning services. Track which meetings offer captions, in what languages, and technical details.

        Typical Workflow: Identify language needs Recruit bilingual members Translate priority materials Schedule interpreters for meetings Offer captioning Monitor accessibility

        Step-by-Step: How to Conduct a Group Conscience Meeting

        Complete GC Meeting Workflow Follow this comprehensive guide to run a proper Group Conscience meeting using this application.

        BEFORE THE MEETING (1-2 Weeks Prior)

        Step 1: Collect Agenda Items

        1. Open Proposed Agenda Items:
          • Navigate to Group Conscience Live GC Session
          • Scroll to "Proposed Agenda Items" section
          • Members can submit items they want discussed
          • Each item should have: Title, Description, Proposer, Category
        2. Review Standing Items:
          • Check Group Conscience GC Inventory for Standing Agenda Items
          • Standard items: Treasury Report, GSR Report, Committee Reports
          • These auto-appear on every GC agenda
        3. Announce the Meeting:
          • Go to Fellowship Announcements
          • Create announcement with: Date, Time, Location, Proposed agenda items
          • Make announcement at regular meetings for 2 weeks prior

        OPENING THE MEETING (First 15 Minutes)

        Step 2: Start Live GC Session

        1. Open the Live Session:
          • Navigate to Group Conscience Live GC Session
          • Click "Start New GC Session"
          • System shows: Attendance tracker, Quorum calculator, Motion workspace
        2. Record Attendance:
          • Count all present members
          • Enter number in "Members Present" field
          • System automatically calculates if quorum is met
          • Quorum rules set in: Settings Quorum Management
          • Note: No quorum = no official votes, but can discuss
        3. Review Agenda:
          • Chairperson reads all proposed items aloud
          • Group votes to adopt the agenda (or modify)
          • Move adopted items to "Active GC Items"
        4. Review Previous Minutes:
          • Go to Reports Meeting Minutes
          • Secretary reads minutes from last GC
          • Group votes to approve (or amend) minutes

        PROCESSING MOTIONS (Main Meeting)

        Step 3: Process Each Motion Using Parliamentary Procedure

        1. Present the Motion:
          • In Live GC section, click "Add New Motion"
          • Enter: Motion text, Proposer name, Motion type (finance/service/policy)
          • Click "Submit Motion"
          • System displays motion on screen for all to see
        2. Call for Second:
          • Chairperson asks: "Do we have a second?"
          • Click "Call for Second" button
          • If no second Motion dies (record as "No Second")
          • If seconded Enter seconder's name, move to discussion
        3. Discussion Phase:
          • Navigate to Group Conscience Parliamentary Procedure for Speaking Queue
          • Members raise hands to speak
          • Add each to speaking queue in order
          • Optional: Set 3-minute timer per speaker
          • During Discussion: Members can use Points of Order:
            • Point of Information: Ask clarifying question (doesn't interrupt)
            • Point of Order: Challenge procedural violation (interrupts)
            • Point of Privilege: Address immediate need (temp, noise, etc.)
        4. Handle Amendments (If Proposed):
          • Scroll to "Amendments" section in Live GC
          • Enter amendment text
          • Select type:
            • Friendly Amendment: Proposer accepts No vote needed
            • Unfriendly Amendment: Must be voted on before main motion
          • If unfriendly: Discuss and vote on amendment first
          • Then return to main motion (as amended or original)
        5. Special Cases:
          • Table Motion: Click "Table Motion" Set date for revisit Motion moves to Tabled Motions (view in GC Decisions)
          • Research Period: If group needs more info, activate Research Period Assign person to research Set deadline Continue at next GC
          • Call the Question: Any member can move to end discussion and vote immediately Requires 2/3 vote to pass If passes, proceed to vote
        6. Vote on Motion:
          • Select voting method (set in Group Conscience Voting Settings):
            • Substantial Unanimity (Default): 2/3 majority (AA standard)
            • Simple Majority: 50% + 1
            • Voice Vote: All say "Aye" or "Nay"
            • Show of Hands: Visual count
            • Written Ballot: Anonymous voting (for sensitive issues)
          • Enter vote counts: For / Against / Abstain
          • Click "Calculate Result"
          • System shows: Passed/Failed, Percentage, Whether substantial unanimity met
        7. Minority Report (Automatic if needed):
          • If motion passes but opposition 33%, system auto-shows Minority Report section
          • Minority can state their concerns for the record
          • This protects minority voice per AA Tradition
          • Record minority concerns Saved with decision
        8. Record the Outcome:
          • System auto-saves to Group Conscience Decision History
          • Includes: Motion text, votes, result, date, minority opinions
          • If motion requires action, create Action Item in Fellowship Action Items

        CLOSING THE MEETING (Final 10 Minutes)

        Step 4: Wrap Up & Documentation

        1. Review Action Items:
          • List all action items from decisions made
          • Go to Fellowship Action Items
          • Assign responsible person and deadline for each
        2. Set Next GC Date:
          • Announce next GC meeting date
          • Add to Meetings Schedule & Calendar
        3. Generate Meeting Minutes:
          • Go to Reports Meeting Minutes
          • Click "Generate Minutes from GC Session"
          • System auto-creates minutes from today's session including:
            • All motions and their outcomes
            • Vote tallies
            • Amendments
            • Minority reports
            • Action items assigned
          • Secretary reviews and can edit if needed
        4. Close the GC Session:
          • Return to Group Conscience Live GC Session
          • Click "End GC Session"
          • All data is saved and archived

        AFTER THE MEETING (Follow-Up)

        Step 5: Implementation & Tracking

        1. Track Implementation:
          • Go to Group Conscience Decision Impact
          • For each passed motion, track:
            • Has it been implemented? (Yes/No/In Progress)
            • Who is responsible?
            • Timeline
            • Impact on group (positive/negative/neutral)
        2. Monitor Action Items:
          • Check Fellowship Action Items weekly
          • Follow up with assigned persons
          • Mark completed when done
        3. Update Financial Records (if applicable):
          • If motion involved money, go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Update budget or record expense/income
          • Treasurer tracks actual vs budgeted amounts
        4. Backup Your Data:
          • Go to Settings (gear icon) Backup & Restore
          • Click "Export All Data"
          • Save backup file with date: rowlett-group-backup-2024-01-15.json
          • Best Practice: Backup after every GC meeting

        Emergency Group Conscience

        For urgent matters that can't wait for regular GC:

        1. Navigate to Home dashboard
        2. Click "Emergency GC Protocol" button in Quick Actions panel
        3. System opens emergency session with relaxed quorum rules
        4. Follow same process as regular GC
        5. Document reason for emergency in session notes

        Getting Started: First-Time Setup

        New Group? Start Here! Follow these steps to set up your group management system from scratch.

        WEEK 1: Initial Setup

        Day 1-2: Add Members & Basic Info

        1. Add all group members:
          • Go to Fellowship Birthdays & Anniversaries
          • Click "Add Member" for each person
          • Enter: Name, Clean Date, Birthday (optional), Phone (optional)
          • Mark if they're a "Servant" (hold service position)
          • Tip: Start with 5-10 active members, add more later
        2. Set up meeting schedule:
          • Go to Meetings Schedule & Calendar
          • Add all regular meeting times (weekly, daily, etc.)
          • Include: Day, Time, Location, Meeting Type, Format
          • Set recurring events (e.g., "Every Monday 7pm")
        3. Create service positions:
          • Go to Service Service Positions
          • Click "Add Position" for each role
          • Standard positions: Chairperson, Secretary, Treasurer, GSR, Literature
          • Enter current holder, start date, term length (typically 6-12 months)
          • System will alert you 30 days before term expires

        Day 3-4: Financial Setup

        1. Set up treasury:
          • Go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Enter current balance in "Starting Balance" field
          • Add all monthly expenses (rent, literature orders, etc.)
          • Add all income sources (7th tradition, donations)
        2. Set prudent reserve:
          • Go to Treasury Prudent Reserve
          • Common formula: 3-6 months of regular expenses
          • Enter monthly rent, utilities, literature costs
          • System calculates recommended reserve target
          • Track progress toward goal
        3. Create budget categories:
          • Go to Treasury Budget Approval
          • Add categories: Rent, Literature, GSO Contributions, District, Area, Supplies
          • Set monthly budget for each
          • System will alert when categories exceed budget

        Day 5-7: Group Conscience Configuration

        1. Set voting method:
          • Go to Group Conscience Voting Settings
          • Choose method: Substantial Unanimity (recommended), Simple Majority, or Consensus
          • Set threshold: 66.7% for substantial unanimity, 51% for majority
          • Decide if abstentions count in total
        2. Configure quorum rules:
          • Go to Settings Quorum Management
          • Set minimum attendance percentage (typically 50%)
          • Set absolute minimum (e.g., 5 people)
          • Decide if you allow proxy voting
        3. Create motion templates:
          • Go to Group Conscience Motion Templates
          • Add common motions your group uses
          • Examples: "Purchase new literature", "Change meeting time", "Elect service position"
          • Templates save time during GC meetings

        WEEK 2: Test Run

        1. Practice with a test GC meeting:
          • Go to Group Conscience Live GC Session
          • Click "Start Group Conscience Meeting"
          • Add a test motion (e.g., "Approve starting balance")
          • Practice recording votes
          • View decision in Decision History
          • This is just practice - you can delete it later!
        2. Create your first backup:
          • Go to Settings (gear icon) Backup & Restore
          • Click "Export Full Backup"
          • Save the JSON file to a safe location (USB drive, cloud storage)
          • Test the backup by importing it in a different browser
          • CRITICAL: Schedule weekly backups - set a reminder!
        3. Announce to the group:
          • Inform members the system is ready
          • Share the URL or file location
          • Explain it's stored locally (no servers, maintains anonymity)
          • Encourage members to view Help & Guide section

        Complete Weekly Meeting Workflow

        Use this workflow every week for consistent, organized meetings.

        24 Hours BEFORE the Meeting

        Secretary/Chairperson Preparation

        1. Review upcoming events:
          • Check Home dashboard for tomorrow's events
          • Verify birthdays and anniversaries
          • Note any announcements to read
        2. Check format rotation:
          • Go to Meetings Format Rotation
          • Confirm which format is scheduled
          • Print or bookmark the reading if needed
        3. Review commitment board:
          • Go to Meetings Commitment Board
          • Check who's scheduled to speak
          • Verify greeter, treasurer, coffee maker
          • Contact members if spots are unfilled
        4. Prepare announcements:
          • Go to Fellowship Announcements
          • Review active announcements
          • Add any new ones (district events, group activities)
          • Mark inactive ones as "ended"

        DURING the Meeting (Live Recording)

        Secretary's Realtime Tasks

        1. Open secretary section:
          • Navigate to Meetings Secretary Functions
          • This section has all tools you need during meeting
        2. Track attendance (as people arrive):
          • Scroll to "Meeting Attendance Tracker"
          • Select today's date
          • Check boxes for each member present
          • Add guest count if applicable
          • System automatically calculates totals
        3. Take meeting minutes (during meeting):
          • Scroll to "Meeting Minutes"
          • Note: Opening (who chaired), Format used, Special events
          • Record any important discussions
          • Note who shared (if your group tracks this)
          • Record closing time
        4. Log 7th tradition (after basket passes):
          • Go to Treasury 7th Tradition Analysis
          • Click "Add Collection"
          • Enter amount collected
          • Note attendance (for per-person average)
          • System tracks trends over time
        5. Record any decisions (if applicable):
          • If group conscience items were discussed
          • Go to Group Conscience Live GC Session
          • Follow GC workflow (see separate section)

        Treasurer's Tasks During Meeting

        1. Count 7th tradition:
          • Count cash immediately after basket passes
          • Have another person verify count (two-person accountability)
          • Enter into system (step 4 above)
        2. Give brief treasurer report (if scheduled):
          • Open Treasury Financial Reports on phone/laptop
          • Report: Current balance, Recent expenses, Prudent reserve status
          • Keep it brief (2-3 minutes maximum)

        AFTER the Meeting (Within 24 Hours)

        Secretary Follow-Up

        1. Finalize minutes:
          • Return to Meetings Secretary Functions
          • Review and clean up any typos
          • Save minutes
          • Optional: Export to PDF for email distribution
        2. Send thank you messages:
          • Go to Fellowship Messages
          • Send quick thanks to speaker, greeter, coffee maker
          • Maintains good fellowship and encourages continued service
        3. Update any action items:
          • If tasks were assigned during meeting
          • Check Home dashboard "Pending Action Items"
          • Update progress or mark complete

        Treasurer Follow-Up

        1. Deposit funds (within 48 hours):
          • Take 7th tradition to bank
          • Get deposit receipt
          • Update balance in system
        2. Record transaction:
          • Go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Click "Add Income"
          • Enter: Date, Amount, Source (7th Tradition), Receipt number
          • New balance updates automatically

        Monthly Treasurer Workflow (The Full Process)

        Complete this workflow on the 1st-5th of every month.

        Week 1: Month-End Reconciliation

        1. Reconcile bank statement:
          • Get bank statement (online or paper)
          • Compare bank balance to system balance
          • Go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Click "Reconcile" button
          • If differences exist:
            • Check for missing deposits or expenses
            • Add any bank fees not yet recorded
            • Add any interest earned
            • Verify all transactions match
        2. Review 7th tradition trends:
          • Go to Treasury 7th Tradition Analysis
          • View charts for last 30/60/90 days
          • Note patterns:
            • Are contributions increasing or decreasing?
            • Is per-person average healthy? (typically $2-5 per meeting)
            • Any concerning trends to report to group?
        3. Update prudent reserve tracking:
          • Go to Treasury Prudent Reserve
          • System auto-calculates current reserve status
          • If below target: Note how many months to reach goal at current rate
          • If above target: Consider contributions to GSO, District, Area
        4. Review budget vs. actual:
          • Go to Treasury Budget Approval
          • Compare budgeted vs. actual spending for each category
          • Flag categories that exceeded budget
          • Note categories well under budget
          • This data helps inform next GC budget discussion

        Week 2: Required Contributions

        1. Calculate contributions (after prudent reserve):
          • Amount available = Current Balance - Prudent Reserve Target
          • If amount is positive, you can contribute
          • Typical split: 50% GSO, 30% District, 20% Area
          • Note: This is a suggestion, not a rule. Your group decides!
        2. Prepare contribution checks/payments:
          • Write checks or prepare online transfers
          • GSO: Mail to General Service Office, PO Box 459, Grand Central Station, New York, NY 10163
          • District: Give to DCM at district meeting or mail per district instructions
          • Area: Give to Area Treasurer or mail per area instructions
          • Include group number and location on all checks
        3. Record contributions in system:
          • Go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Click "Add Expense" for each contribution
          • Category: "GSO Contribution", "District Contribution", "Area Contribution"
          • Enter check numbers and amounts
          • System tracks total contributed over time

        Week 3: Monthly Report Preparation

        1. Generate monthly report:
          • Go to Treasury Financial Reports
          • Click "Generate Monthly Report"
          • Select last month from dropdown
          • Report includes:
            • Opening balance
            • Total income (7th tradition, donations)
            • Total expenses by category
            • Closing balance
            • Prudent reserve status
            • Contributions made
        2. Export report for distribution:
          • Click "Export to PDF"
          • Email to group or print for display at meetings
          • Or simply display on screen during meeting
        3. Prepare verbal report for group:
          • Keep it simple and brief (3 minutes max)
          • Sample script: "Our opening balance was $X. We collected $Y in 7th tradition. We spent $Z on [major expenses]. Our closing balance is $A. Our prudent reserve target is $B, and we're at X% of that goal. We contributed $C to GSO/District/Area this month. Any questions?"

        Week 4: Maintenance & Planning

        1. Review upcoming expenses:
          • Check calendar for next month's known expenses
          • Rent due dates
          • Literature orders needed
          • Chips inventory low?
          • Any service position conferences/workshops
        2. Create backup of financial data:
          • Go to Settings Backup & Restore
          • Export full backup
          • Save with date: "GroupBackup-YYYY-MM-DD.json"
          • Store in multiple locations (USB + cloud)
        3. If needed, schedule budget GC:
          • If expenses consistently exceed income
          • If major purchase needed
          • If prudent reserve not being reached
          • Propose GC agenda item to address financial situation

        Quarterly Service Rotation Workflow

        Service positions typically rotate every 6-12 months. Use this workflow 30 days before rotation.

        30 Days Before Term Ends

        System Will Auto-Alert

        The system automatically checks term expiration dates and will show notification on Home dashboard.

        1. Review expiring positions:
          • Go to Service Service Positions
          • Click "View Expiring Soon"
          • Note which positions need elections
        2. Announce upcoming elections:
          • At business meeting, announce which positions will rotate
          • Explain qualifications for each position (per your bylaws)
          • Encourage members to consider service
          • Give 2-4 weeks notice before election
        3. Create GC agenda item:
          • Go to Group Conscience Decision History
          • Scroll to "Proposed Agenda Items"
          • Add item: "Election for [Position Name]"
          • Include qualifications and responsibilities
          • Set for next scheduled GC meeting

        Election Day (At GC Meeting)

        1. Set up election in system:
          • Go to Service Service Elections
          • Click "Start New Election"
          • Select position from dropdown
          • Choose election method:
            • Third Legacy: Requires 2/3 vote, multiple rounds if needed
            • Simple Vote: Highest vote total wins
            • Consensus: Must have unanimous agreement
        2. Call for nominations:
          • Chairperson asks: "Are there any nominations for [Position]?"
          • Secretary enters each nomination in system
          • Enter nominee name from member dropdown
          • Note: Some groups require nominee acceptance before voting
          • Close nominations when no more are offered
        3. Conduct voting:
          • Click "Begin Voting"
          • System displays all nominees
          • Record votes for each nominee
          • If using Third Legacy:
            • System calculates if anyone reached 2/3
            • If not, proceed to second round
            • Remove nominee(s) with fewest votes
            • Re-vote until someone reaches threshold
          • System declares winner automatically
        4. Record the election result:
          • Winner is automatically saved
          • System updates Service Positions with new holder
          • Start date set to today (or date specified)
          • Term expiration calculated automatically
          • You'll get reminder again when term approaches end

        After Election (Transition Period)

        1. Outgoing servant creates transition document:
          • Go to Resources Document Templates
          • Use "Service Position Transition" template
          • Include:
            • Key contacts (bank, landlord, suppliers, etc.)
            • Account numbers and passwords
            • Recurring tasks and their schedules
            • Lessons learned and helpful tips
            • Pending tasks to complete
          • Export to PDF and share with incoming servant
        2. Schedule orientation meeting:
          • Outgoing and incoming servants meet in person
          • Review transition document together
          • Transfer any physical items (keys, checkbook, etc.)
          • Update bank signature cards if needed
          • Add incoming servant to relevant email lists
        3. Update system access:
          • If using role-based access control
          • Go to Settings Role & View Settings
          • Update permissions for new position holder
          • Remove old holder's extra permissions
        4. Celebrate the service!
          • At next meeting, formally recognize outgoing servant
          • Optional: Give anniversary chip if they served full term
          • Welcome new servant publicly
          • This encourages continued service in the fellowship

        Emergency & Crisis Scenarios

        Sometimes urgent decisions must be made. Here's how to handle various crisis situations.

        Scenario 1: Sudden Loss of Meeting Space

        Situation: Your landlord just gave you 7-day notice that you can't meet there anymore.

        Immediate Actions (Day 1):

        1. Call emergency GC:
          • Go to Home dashboard
          • Click "Emergency GC Protocol" button in Quick Actions
          • Document the situation in detail
          • Set emergency meeting date (within 48 hours)
        2. Notify all members immediately:
          • Use Fellowship Messages to send blast message
          • Text/call key members directly
          • Post announcement at meeting location
          • Include: Date/time of emergency GC, Situation summary, Urgency level
        3. Research alternative locations:
          • Contact nearby churches, community centers, libraries
          • Check other AA groups for space-sharing possibilities
          • Document: Location, Cost, Availability, Contact person
          • Add findings to "Emergency GC" notes

        Emergency GC Meeting (Within 48 Hours):

        1. Present options:
          • Share all researched locations with pros/cons
          • Include cost comparison, accessibility, parking
          • Note immediate availability
        2. Make quick decision:
          • Group votes on interim solution
          • Record decision in Emergency GC log
          • Assign action items: Contact new location, move supplies, update meeting list
        3. Update all directories:
          • Update location in Meetings Schedule
          • Contact Area/District meeting list chair
          • Update aa.org meeting finder
          • Post notices at old location with new address

        Scenario 2: Treasury Emergency (Unauthorized Spending)

        Situation: You discover the treasurer made large unauthorized purchases, balance is critically low.

        Immediate Actions:

        1. Verify the situation:
          • Check bank statement against system records
          • Document all unauthorized transactions
          • Take screenshots/photos of evidence
          • Determine current actual balance
        2. Protect the treasury immediately:
          • If possible, freeze bank account temporarily
          • Remove treasurer from account access
          • Assign interim treasurer if needed
          • Change any online banking passwords
        3. Call emergency GC:
          • Initiate emergency GC in system
          • Notify trusted servants immediately
          • Schedule meeting within 48 hours
          • Important: Handle with love and compassion - addiction often plays a role
        4. Document everything:
          • Go to Settings Audit Log
          • Export all treasury activity logs
          • Create timeline of events
          • This protects both group and individual

        At Emergency GC:

        1. Address the financial situation:
          • Present facts without judgment
          • Show bank statement vs. system records
          • Determine if theft or accounting error
          • If theft: Group decides whether to involve authorities (usually not, per traditions)
        2. Implement new safeguards:
          • Require two signatures on checks over $X
          • Monthly treasurer reports to group (not optional)
          • Quarterly audit by non-treasurer member
          • Two-person count of 7th tradition
          • Regular backups of financial records
        3. Elect new treasurer immediately:
          • Use Service Service Elections
          • Emergency election to fill position
          • New treasurer verifies all accounts day one
        4. Create repayment plan (if applicable):
          • If member admits mistake and wants to make amends
          • Group can accept repayment plan
          • Track in system as special income category
          • Approach with compassion and support recovery

        Scenario 3: Disruptive Member (Safety Issue)

        Situation: A member is repeatedly disruptive, threatening, or creating unsafe environment. Other members are staying away.

        Immediate Safety First:

        1. At the moment of incident:
          • Chairperson calmly but firmly addresses behavior
          • "[Name], your behavior is disruptive. Please step outside to cool down."
          • If threatening: Call police, evacuate if necessary
          • Safety of group always comes first
        2. Document the incident:
          • Go to Meetings Secretary Functions
          • In meeting minutes, factually describe what happened
          • Note: Date, time, specific behaviors, any threats made
          • List witnesses present
          • Keep emotions out of documentation

        Schedule Group Conscience:

        1. Create GC agenda item:
          • Go to Group Conscience Decision History
          • Add proposed item: "Address disruptive behavior and group safety"
          • Include summary of incidents
          • Set for next GC or call emergency GC if severe
        2. Research AA's guidance:
          • Review Tradition 1 (Unity) and Tradition 4 (Autonomy)
          • Read "AA Guidelines on Safety in AA"
          • Consult with Area/District if needed
          • Remember: AA is not a refuge from consequences of bad behavior

        At Group Conscience:

        1. Present the situation:
          • Read documented incidents objectively
          • Discuss impact on group unity and safety
          • Share member feedback (anonymously)
        2. Discuss options with compassion:
          • Option 1: Have group members talk to person individually
          • Option 2: Set behavioral expectations in writing
          • Option 3: Ask person not to attend for 30/60/90 days
          • Option 4: Permanently ban from this meeting (suggest other meetings)
          • Remember: We can't ban from AA, only from our meeting
        3. Vote and implement decision:
          • Record GC decision in system
          • Assign 2-3 trusted servants to communicate decision
          • Put in writing if person is asked to stay away
          • Include timeframe and conditions for return (if applicable)
          • Follow up: Check in with group regularly on safety

        Important Reminders:

        • Document everything for potential liability protection
        • Balance compassion with safety - both are important
        • Suggest other meetings if asking someone to leave
        • Consider if substance use is active factor
        • Consult Area/District chair or experienced groups
        • Never tolerate threats or violence - call police

        Advanced Features & Special Scenarios

        Using Decision ROI Calculator (Financial Decisions)

        When to use: Any financial decision over $500 or recurring expense

        Example: Group considering buying a coffee maker vs. continuing to make at home

        Step-by-Step Process:

        1. Go to Group Conscience Decision History, scroll to "Decision ROI Calculator"
        2. Enter decision title: "Purchase commercial coffee maker"
        3. Initial cost: $450 (coffee maker cost)
        4. Ongoing monthly cost: $40 (coffee, filters)
        5. Monthly expense savings: $0 (we already make coffee)
        6. Revenue impact: $30 (estimated additional donations from better coffee)
        7. Timeframe: 24 months (expected lifespan)
        8. Click "Calculate ROI"
        9. Result: System shows:
          • Total cost: $1410 over 24 months
          • Total benefit: $720 (additional donations)
          • Net impact: -$690 (negative)
          • Payback: Never breaks even
          • Recommendation: Not recommended financially
        10. Present to group at GC: "The ROI calculator shows this would cost us $690 over 2 years with no financial benefit. However, there may be non-financial benefits like fellowship and member satisfaction. Let's discuss."
        11. Group can still approve if non-financial benefits outweigh cost
        12. Save calculation in system for future reference

        Motion Reconsideration (Changing a Past Decision)

        When appropriate: Significant new information emerged, circumstances changed drastically, original decision having unintended consequences

        Warning: Reconsideration should be RARE. Frequent reconsideration undermines group conscience authority.

        Proper Process:

        1. Submit reconsideration request:
          • Go to "Motion Reconsideration Workflow" section
          • Select original decision from dropdown
          • Choose reason: "Significant new information" (most common valid reason)
          • Write detailed justification - what NEW information wasn't available before?
          • Submit request
        2. Request goes to review:
          • Chairperson/secretary reviews request
          • Determines if justification is substantial enough
          • If yes: Add to next GC agenda
          • If no: Deny with explanation
        3. At GC meeting:
          • Present original decision and circumstances
          • Present new information that changed situation
          • Allow discussion
          • Vote on whether to reconsider (requires 2/3 vote in most groups)
          • If passes: Proceed with new discussion and vote on revised motion
        4. Track in system:
          • New decision linked to original decision
          • Both show in Decision History
          • Analytics track reconsideration patterns
          • If you frequently reconsider: There's a deeper group issue to address

        Example of VALID Reconsideration:

        "In January, we voted to move meeting time to 7pm. We didn't know that the building closes at 8pm on weeknights. We've been locked out twice. New information: Building availability. Request to reconsider meeting time."

        Example of INVALID Reconsideration:

        "We voted to buy new literature two months ago. I disagree with that decision and want to reconsider."

        This is not new information - just disagreement. Reconsideration denied.

        Proxy Voting (When Allowed)

        Check Your Bylaws! Not all groups allow proxy voting. Verify before implementing.

        How to Set Up Proxy:

        1. Member who will be absent:
          • Go to "Proxy Voting System"
          • Select your name from "Your Name" dropdown
          • Select trusted member from "Designate Proxy To"
          • Choose scope:
            • General: They vote as they see fit
            • Directed: You specify exactly how to vote
          • If directed: Enter specific instructions
          • Enter meeting date (proxy only valid for that date)
          • Submit proxy designation
        2. At GC meeting:
          • Secretary announces proxies: "[Name] has designated [Proxy holder] to vote on their behalf"
          • If general proxy: Holder votes their conscience
          • If directed proxy: Holder votes as instructed
          • System tracks proxy votes separately in voting records
        3. Proxy expires:
          • Automatically expires after meeting date
          • Member can revoke anytime before meeting
          • Must be re-designated for each meeting

        Annual Group Inventory Process

        When: Once per year, typically in January or on group anniversary

        Purpose: Honest self-assessment of group health, effectiveness, and adherence to traditions

        6 Weeks Before Inventory:

        1. Schedule inventory date:
          • Go to Settings Group Inventory Scheduler
          • Set date (typically 2-3 hour dedicated meeting)
          • System sends reminders to all members
        2. Generate inventory questions:
          • System provides template based on 12 Traditions
          • Add custom questions specific to your group
          • Examples:
            • "Are we attracting new members effectively?"
            • "Is our 7th tradition meeting our needs?"
            • "Are service positions filled and functioning?"
            • "Do members feel heard in GC meetings?"
            • "Are we carrying the message effectively?"
        3. Send inventory survey:
          • Use Meetings Meeting Feedback Survey
          • Adapt questions for annual inventory
          • Allow anonymous responses
          • Give members 2 weeks to complete

        At Inventory Meeting:

        1. Review analytics:
          • Present data from Reports Group Analytics
          • Show attendance trends, financial health, decision patterns
          • Compare to previous year
        2. Discuss each tradition:
          • Go through 12 Traditions one at a time
          • Ask: "How well are we practicing this tradition?"
          • Rate each tradition: Excellent / Good / Needs Attention / Poor
          • Use Unity Checker to identify specific issues
        3. Create action items:
          • For each "Needs Attention" area, create action item
          • Assign to specific member or committee
          • Set reasonable deadlines
          • Track in Home dashboard action items
        4. Set goals for coming year:
          • Based on inventory findings
          • Make them specific and measurable
          • Example: "Increase average attendance by 10%"
          • Example: "Fill all service positions within 30 days"
          • Example: "Reach prudent reserve target by December"
        5. Document everything:
          • Save inventory results in system
          • Export report for future reference
          • Compare next year to show progress

          What is 90-in-90?

          A suggestion for newcomers to attend 90 AA meetings in 90 days. This helps build the foundation of recovery, develop a support network, and make sobriety a daily priority.

          About Sponsorship

          A sponsor is an AA member who has made progress in the recovery program and shares that experience with another member. They guide you through the Twelve Steps, provide support, and help you navigate the challenges of sobriety.

          A 12-step call is when an AA member reaches out to help someone who is suffering from alcoholism - whether they're new to the program, contemplating sobriety, or experiencing a crisis. It's one of the most important services we provide.
